study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silver nanoparticles synthesized from Boswellia dalzielii stem bark extract could inhibit the proliferation of Kasumi-1 leukemia cells and induce cell cycle arrest.
results_summary: The synthesized silver nanoparticles demonstrated antioxidant capacity and effectively inhibited Kasumi-1 leukemia cell proliferation, with IC50 values of 49.5 μg/ml at 48 hours and 13.25 μg/ml at 72 hours. The nanoparticles also induced cell cycle arrest at the S and G2/M phases.
population_specificity: Kasumi-1 leukemia cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the synergistic effects of Boswellia serrata combined with L-cysteine and whey protein on antioxidant properties, shelf life, and sensory characteristics of pork patties.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia serrata, when combined with cysteine and whey protein (WBC treatment), significantly enhanced DPPH radical-scavenging activity, sensory characteristics, and reduced TBARS and MetMb values, indicating improved antioxidant effects and shelf life. The combination also improved water holding capacity and reduced cooking loss and hardness in pork patties.
population_specificity: Pork patties (in vitro food model)
effective_dosage: 1% Boswellia serrata (combined with 2% whey and 0.25% cysteine)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate the antibacterial constituents of Boswellia dalzielii stem bark and validate its traditional use in treating bacterial infections.
results_summary: The study isolated 14 compounds, including dalzienoside (newly reported), and found that α-boswellic acid, β-boswellic acid, and acetyl-11-keto-β-boswellic acid exhibited strong antibacterial activity against multiple bacterial strains, with MIC values as low as 3.125 µg/mL. The crude extract and fractions also showed moderate to significant antibacterial effects.
population_specificity: Bacterial strains (Staphylococcus aureus, Salmonella typhi, Enterobacter cloacae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa).
effective_dosage: MIC values: crude extract (250 µL/mL), fractions (7.8–125 µg/mL), compounds (3.125 µg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a herbal combination including Boswellia serrata could improve cognitive impairment and reduce oxidative brain damage in hypothyroid rats.
results_summary: The herbal combination, including Boswellia, significantly improved memory impairment, reduced oxidative damage markers, and enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity in the brain of hypothyroid rats. The effects were comparable to donepezil, a standard treatment for cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: Hypothyroid rats induced by propylthiouracil (PTU) administration.
effective_dosage: 640 and 1,280 mg/kg of the herbal combination (including Boswellia) mixed with honey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Boswellia serrata extract with bacterial nanocellulose (BNC) via nanoemulsions could overcome hydrophilicity challenges for effective anti-inflammatory skin treatment.
results_summary: The study found that nanoemulsions successfully incorporated Boswellia serrata extract into BNC without altering its key properties, demonstrated biphasic drug release, and confirmed biocompatibility ex ovo. Drug penetration into skin depended on nanoemulsion type, application frequency, and incubation time.
population_specificity: Not specified (ex ovo and porcine skin models used).
study_duration: Storage stability tested over 30 days; intervention duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic effects and impact on glycoprotein metabolism of an aqueous extract of Boswellia ovalifoliolata stem bark in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Treatment with the extract significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, increased insulin and hemoglobin levels, and decreased glycosylated hemoglobin. It also lowered glycoprotein levels in plasma, liver, and kidney tissues.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of Boswellia serrata and its extracts in treating osteoarthritis (OA) symptoms compared to placebo or western medicine.
results_summary: Boswellia and its extracts significantly reduced pain, stiffness, and improved joint function in OA patients, with statistically significant results across multiple outcome measures. The study concluded that Boswellia is an effective and safe treatment option for OA.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (545 participants across 7 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Boswellia serrata gum resin influences GAD65 autoantibodies, a marker associated with LADA (Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adults).
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia serrata gum resin treatment led to a 25% linear decrease in GAD65 autoantibodies over 9 months, suggesting potential benefits in preventing insulitis in LADA patients.
population_specificity: A male patient diagnosed with LADA and positive GAD65 autoantibodies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of SLBSP (a Boswellia extract) versus standardized BSE for treating symptomatic knee osteoarthritis, focusing on pain relief, functional improvement, and inflammatory cytokine modulation.
results_summary: Both SLBSP and BSE showed significant improvements in pain and function (WOMAC and VAS scores), with no statistically significant difference between them. SLBSP was superior in reducing the need for rescue analgesics and lowering pro-inflammatory cytokine levels compared to BSE.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Boswellia species and their main constituents, boswellic acids, as modulators of mechanisms involved in neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia species exhibit neuroprotective effects through antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, antiamyloidogenic, and anti-apoptotic properties, supported by in vitro, animal, and clinical studies. These bioactive components may enhance cognitive activity and protect against neurodegeneration.
population_specificity: Not specified (includes in vitro, animal, and clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the testicular toxicity of standardized methanolic extract of Boswellia sacra oleo gum resin in rats through repeated oral dose administration.
results_summary: The extract did not cause significant behavioral, weight, or histological changes but significantly decreased serum testosterone levels at the highest dose (1000 mg/kg). Gene expression analysis revealed antioxidant potential, suggesting protective effects against toxicants.
population_specificity: Male rats
effective_dosage: Three doses (highest tested dose was 1000 mg/kg, orally)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Boswellia serrata resin (BSR) supplementation in broiler chicken diets on fatty acid profiles in tissues and meat quality.
results_summary: BSR supplementation improved polyunsaturated fatty acid content in breast and drumstick muscles and abdominal fat, enhanced dietary parameters (n-3/n-6 ratio, saturation indices), and improved physicochemical properties like water-holding capacity and cooking losses. The color parameter a* decreased in breast muscles with higher BSR doses.
population_specificity: Ross 308 broiler chickens

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the population structure of Boswellia papyrifera and prioritize conservation intervention alternatives using Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP) modelling techniques.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia papyrifera populations are unstable, with low density (266 trees ha-1), absence of regeneration, and saplings due to overgrazing, over-tapping, pests, agricultural expansion, and poor management. The AHP analysis identified area exclosure with medium (AEMTR) and long (AELTR) tapping resting periods as the best conservation strategies.
population_specificity: Boswellia papyrifera woodlands in the Abergele district, northern Ethiopia.
study_duration: Not applicable (conservation study, not an intervention trial)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of repeated administration of Boswellia sacra extract on liver and kidney functions in rats, assessing sub-chronic toxicity.
results_summary: The study found no significant behavioral toxicity, changes in food consumption, or weight gain. Biomarkers and histological examination indicated safety at tested doses, with only a dose-dependent increase in serum total protein levels.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether pharmacokinetic interactions occur among the major constituents of Boswellia serrata extract and other supplements when administered alone or in combination.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the pharmacokinetic profiles of Boswellia's constituents when administered in combination with other supplements compared to when administered alone, suggesting no pharmacokinetic interactions.
population_specificity: 16 healthy participants
study_duration: Single-dose administration with 1-week washout between treatments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy and safety of a transrectal association of Boswellia resin extract and propolis-derived polyphenols for relieving prostatitis-like symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the Boswellia-propolis combination significantly reduced genitourinary pain and improved quality of life, with a 28.5% reduction in pain domain scores and no significant adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Men aged ≥18 with chronic/recurrent prostatitis-like symptoms persisting for at least 3 of the last 6 months.
effective_dosage: 1 suppository containing Boswellia resin extract and propolis-derived polyphenols, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-fibrotic effects of Boswellia serrata gum resin against CCl4-induced liver damage in rats.
results_summary: Boswellia significantly reduced liver damage markers (AST, ALT, LDH), restored bilirubin, triglyceride, and albumin levels, alleviated oxidative stress, and lowered inflammatory markers (TNF-α, NF-κB, TGF-β, IL-6, COX-2). It also exhibited antifibrotic activity in histopathological analysis.
population_specificity: Rats with CCl4-induced liver fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory activities of bioactive compounds in purified fractions of Boswellia serrata, specifically focusing on leukotriene and COX-2 inhibition in vitro and lung inflammation reduction in vivo.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia serrata ethanolic extracts significantly reduced leukotriene-C4-synthase (52%), leukotriene-A4-hydrolase (22%), and COX-2 (99%) activities in vitro. In vivo, oral administration reduced OVA-induced lung inflammation by ~51% in mice, though less effectively than dexamethasone (~66%).
population_specificity: Human leukemia (HL-60) cells and OVA-sensitized BALB/c mice.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 100 mg/kg body weight (oral administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Proxelan® (Boswellia) monotherapy on pain symptoms in patients with chronic prostatitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.
results_summary: Proxelan® monotherapy significantly reduced pain symptoms, urinary symptoms, and improved quality of life. It also decreased IL6 levels and increased sperm motility, though leukocytospermia persisted in some patients.
population_specificity: Men under 50 with chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome, no urinary obstruction, PSA <4 ng/mL, and negative microbiology tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the concentrations of AKBA and KBA in human and canine Boswellia serrata extract (BSE) formulations and compare them to label claims.
results_summary: The study found large variations in AKBA and KBA concentrations across market formulations, with products claiming AKBA containing significantly higher levels. Label claims for AKBA were exceeded, but KBA was undetectable in some products.
population_specificity: Canine and human Boswellia serrata extract formulations.
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations measured in mg/g AF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-arthritic activity of Boswellia serrata extract (BSE) in rats with induced rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: BSE at 180 mg/kg showed significant improvement in body weight, reduced ankle diameter and arthritic index, but no significant change in paw volume or TNF-α levels. Histopathological results indicated reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with CFA-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Boswellia serrata resin extract could improve motor dysfunction and reduce oxidative stress in a rat model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Boswellia extract significantly reduced motor impairments (rotational behavior and narrow beam test performance) in rats with induced Parkinson's disease, though oxidative stress markers showed no significant changes. The effects were dose-dependent, with 125 mg/kg and 250 mg/kg showing the most consistent improvements.
population_specificity: Male rats with induced Parkinson's disease (intrastriatal 6-OHDA model).
effective_dosage: 125 mg/kg, 250 mg/kg, and 500 mg/kg (administered for 3 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for quantifying boswellic and lupeolic acids in Boswellia species and evaluate their cytotoxic effects against a treatment-resistant breast cancer cell line.
results_summary: The study developed a sensitive HPLC-MS/MS method to analyze triterpenic acids in Boswellia oleogum resins, identifying species-specific and geographic variations in composition. Extracts, particularly from B. sacra, showed potent cytotoxicity against MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells, with efficacy correlating with triterpenic acid content.
population_specificity: Human metastatic breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231 (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 for B. sacra extract was 8.3 ± 0.6 µg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antibacterial effects of Boswellia serrata hydroalcoholic extract against Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, a periodontal pathogen.
results_summary: Boswellia serrata hydroalcoholic extract showed antimicrobial activity against A. actinomycetemcomitans, with a minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of 1666 μg/mL, though significantly less effective than chlorhexidine (3.33 μg/mL).
population_specificity: In vitro study (bacterial culture of A. actinomycetemcomitans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a standardized Boswellia serrata extract (BSE) containing AKBBA and BBA in improving physical function and reducing inflammation in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: BSE significantly improved physical function, reduced pain and stiffness, and decreased inflammatory markers compared to placebo. Radiographic assessments confirmed improved joint gap and reduced osteophytes, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: 48 patients with osteoarthritis of the knee.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a dietary supplement containing Boswellia on persistent knee discomfort in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Boswellia's effects.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects aged 40 years and older with persistent knee discomfort (pain intensity > 3 on a 1-10 cm VAS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing potential and mechanism of action of Boswellia serrata extract in a diabetic foot ulcer model.
results_summary: Boswellia serrata (200 and 400 mg/kg) significantly improved wound contraction, reduced oxidative-inflammatory markers, increased collagen synthesis and angiogenesis, and inhibited apoptosis in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a supplement combination containing Boswellia serrata extract, among other ingredients, could effectively reduce hand pain in people with hand osteoarthritis compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain reduction between the supplement combination group (which included Boswellia) and the placebo group over 12 weeks. Adverse event-related discontinuations were slightly higher in the supplement group (10%) compared to placebo (7%).
population_specificity: Adults aged over 40 with symptomatic hand osteoarthritis (radiographically confirmed, Kellgren Lawrence grade ≥ 2), predominantly women (81%).
effective_dosage: Boswellia serrata extract 250 mg/day (as part of a multi-ingredient supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the safety, herb-drug interactions, and appropriate uses of Boswellia in the oncology setting based on literature reviews.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Boswellia's effects, only noting its popularity among searched supplements and the general lack of well-designed studies in cancer patients.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (oncology setting)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether current research on Boswellia provides sufficient evidence to inform decisions for practice and self-care, specifically for chronic musculoskeletal pain in Special Operations Forces personnel.
results_summary: The study found insufficient strong research on Boswellia to make any recommendations for its use as a supplement for chronic musculoskeletal pain. No conclusions were drawn due to low-quality evidence.
population_specificity: Special Operations Forces personnel with chronic musculoskeletal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Acidif plus® (containing Boswellia serrata) in treating uncomplicated UTIs in women compared to standard antibiotic therapy.
results_summary: Acidif plus® was found non-inferior to fosfomycin, with over 50% of patients symptom-free and 85% showing bacterial elimination in urine cultures post-treatment. It was more effective than fosfomycin in symptom alleviation and bacterial clearance.
population_specificity: Women with uncomplicated UTIs (symptomatic or asymptomatic, bacteriuria-positive).
effective_dosage: 2 tablets per day (1 morning, 1 evening) for 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of a supplement combination, including Boswellia, for treating symptomatic hand osteoarthritis compared to placebo.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Boswellia's effects, as it describes the study protocol rather than outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults aged over 40 with painful hand osteoarthritis and structural changes on X-ray (Kellgren and Lawrence grade ≥2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing evidence and recommendations supporting the use of Boswellia serrata extract for osteoarthritis (OA) symptom relief.
results_summary: Limited research evidence supports the oral use of Boswellia serrata extract for OA, though the available studies were of poor quality. The products were generally recognized as safe, but few studies adequately reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: People with osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of a lecithin-based delivery form of Boswellia serrata (Casperome®) for preventing symptoms in otherwise healthy subjects with mild irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The Boswellia group showed lower mean scores for IBS symptoms, reduced need for rescue medications, and fewer medical consultations compared to the standard management group. Oxidative stress was significantly decreased in Boswellia-supplemented subjects, and adverse events were minimal.
population_specificity: Otherwise healthy participants with mild IBS (69 subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Casperome®, a lecithin-based Boswellia serrata extract, in treating musculoskeletal disorders such as Achilles tendonitis, epicondylitis, and sport injuries.
results_summary: Casperome® demonstrated prompt pain reduction, improved functionality, and reduced inflammatory markers without significant adverse effects. Clinical studies, including randomized designs, consistently supported its efficacy in musculoskeletal conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal disorders (e.g., Achilles tendonitis, epicondylitis, radiculopathies, ankle sprains, sport injuries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a food supplement containing Boswellia serrata extracts as an alternative or adjuvant treatment for symptomatic UTIs in pregnancy.
results_summary: The food supplement showed significant efficacy, with 70.0% of treated patients achieving negative urine cultures at 7 days, compared to 43.2% in the control group. Symptoms disappeared in 62.5% of treated patients, and no side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with symptomatic cystitis.
study_duration: 1 week (with an optional additional week for some patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the evidence for dietary supplements, including Boswellia, in managing inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Boswellia's effects on IBD.
population_specificity: IBD patients (no specific subgroup mentioned for Boswellia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with curcumin and Boswellia serrata extract (BSE) could reduce glycoxidation and lipid peroxidation in chronically exercising master athletes.
results_summary: The study found that the curcumin/BSE group showed a significant decline in total AGEs, while both groups experienced reductions in sRAGE, NEFA, and MDA. Only the changes in total AGE and MDA differed significantly between the curcumin/BSE and MD groups.
population_specificity: Healthy male athletes engaged in chronic intensive exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current literature on the efficacy and adverse effects of Boswellia serrata as a dietary supplement for treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Boswellia's effects, but it indicates that the review includes an evaluation of its efficacy and adverse effects for IBD treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a supplement containing Boswellia serrata and curcumin on eicosanoid derivatives in early-stage chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant group effect for prostaglandin E (PGE) and a trend for a Group × Time interaction, suggesting potential anti-inflammatory effects of the supplement in early-stage CKD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with stage 2 and stage 3 CKD who had not initiated hemodialysis (n=16, mean age 56.0 ± 16.0 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a herbal supplement containing Boswellia serrata and Curcuma longa could reduce systemic inflammation and improve antioxidant status in non-dialysis CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in IL-6 levels, indicating potential anti-inflammatory effects, but no significant changes in TNF-α, CRP, or GPx. The supplement was deemed safe and tolerable.
population_specificity: Non-dialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients (n=16, mean age 56.0±16.0 yrs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a dietary supplement containing Boswellia serrata and Curcuma longa could reduce postoperative pain in patients undergoing arthroscopic supraspinatus tendon repair.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced pain at 1 week post-surgery compared to placebo, with modest effects at 2 weeks, but no significant differences in long-term pain. Patient global assessment scores were good across all subjects.
population_specificity: Patients with full-thickness supraspinatus tendon tears treated by arthroscopy.
study_duration: 2 months (3 weeks pre-surgery and continued post-surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could effectively resolve vascular failure, prolonged bleeding, and defect widening in surgically perforated stomach lesions in rats, and to explore its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: BPC-157 rapidly restored blood vessel function, reduced bleeding, contracted defects, and promoted advanced healing with fewer adhesions, while also normalizing malondialdehyde and nitric oxide levels and influencing gene expression related to healing pathways.
population_specificity: Rats with surgically perforated stomach lesions.
effective_dosage: 0.01 μg/kg administered as an abdominal bath.
study_duration: Immediate effects observed within 1-15 minutes post-injury; healing assessed at day 1 and day 7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the effects of isoprenaline-induced myocardial infarction and multiorgan failure in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 reduced necrosis markers, attenuated organ damage, and improved cardiac function by decreasing oxidative stress and maintaining NO system function. It also counteracted the harmful effects of the NOS-blocker L-NAME.
population_specificity: Rats treated with isoprenaline to induce myocardial infarction and multiorgan failure.
interactions: Counteracted the noxious effect of L-NAME (NOS-blocker).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157's ability to counteract venous occlusion-induced syndromes, including ischemia-reperfusion injury and Budd-Chiari syndrome, and its cytoprotective effects.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated effectiveness in resolving major vessel occlusion disturbances, maintaining endothelium and epithelium, and stabilizing membranes. It showed therapeutic potential in ulcerative colitis and multiple sclerosis trials, with no reported lethal dose.
population_specificity: Not specified (generalized from in vitro and animal models, with references to human trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157 as a potential prophylactic and complementary treatment for COVID-19, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, cytoprotective, and endothelial-protective effects.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated anti-inflammatory, cytoprotective, and endothelial-protective effects in animal models, improving vascular integrity, immune response, and reducing proinflammatory profiles. The peptide's activation of eNOS and NO release was associated with tissue repair and angiomodulatory properties.
population_specificity: Animal models (species not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the harmful effects of abdominal compartment syndrome by improving venous function and activating collateral pathways.
results_summary: BPC-157 administration reversed multiple adverse effects of intra-abdominal hypertension, including venous and arterial thrombosis, organ congestion, and severe ECG disturbances, while restoring failed collateral pathways and preventing tissue damage. Microscopic analysis confirmed reduced hyperemia, congestion, and structural damage in multiple organs.
population_specificity: Thiopental- and esketamine-anesthetized rats with induced abdominal compartment syndrome.
study_duration: Single dose administered after 10 minutes of induced hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of BPC-157 on healing a myotendinous junction defect in rats, which does not heal spontaneously.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated significant therapeutic effects, including improved macroscopic and microscopic healing, biomechanical and functional recovery, reduced oxidative stress, and normalized eNOS and COX-2 mRNA levels. Treated rats showed complete defect resolution and no inflammatory infiltrate by 28-42 days.
population_specificity: Rats with surgically induced myotendinous junction defects.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg and 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally; 0.16 µg/mL and 0.16 ng/mL orally in drinking water (12 mL/rat/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the severe occlusive-like syndrome and multi-organ dysfunction induced by high-dose lithium in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted lithium-induced syndromes, including intracranial and portal hypertension, aortal hypotension, thrombosis, and multi-organ damage, while attenuating oxidative stress and improving vascular and organ function.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to high-dose lithium sulfate (500 mg/kg/day, ip, for 3 days).
effective_dosage: Not specified for BPC-157 (only lithium dosage provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytoprotective effects of BPC-157 in counteracting alcohol-induced systemic damage, including gastric lesions, vascular congestion, and organ injuries.
results_summary: BPC-157 rapidly reversed alcohol-induced damage, including brain swelling, vascular congestion, and organ lesions, while improving collateral blood flow and mitigating microscopic tissue damage.
population_specificity: Animal models (specific species not mentioned)
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg, administered intraperitoneally 1 minute after alcohol

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of BPC-157 supplementation on biochemical and immunological parameters in honeybees, focusing on physiological changes and immune response.
results_summary: BPC-157 administration led to positive physiological changes in honeybees, including enhanced enzymatic activity (LAP) in mid-guts and improved immune markers, compared to control groups.
population_specificity: Newly emerged worker honeybees in laboratory-controlled conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of BPC-157 in healing vesicovaginal fistulas and preventing bladder stone formation in rats with delayed treatment initiation.
results_summary: BPC-157 therapy reversed poor healing, stopped urinary leakage, improved tissue regeneration (epithelization, collagenization, granulation, neovascularization), reduced inflammation and necrosis, and prevented stone formation, with both µg and ng regimens showing efficacy.
population_specificity: Rats with well-formed 2-week vesicovaginal fistulas.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg, administered intraperitoneally once daily or orally in drinking water.
study_duration: Until sacrifice (exact duration not specified, but outcomes were assessed up to 6 weeks post-therapy initiation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could activate alternative vascular pathways and counteract the effects of occluded superior mesenteric vessels in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 rapidly activated collateral vascular pathways, counteracted hypertension and hypotension, reduced thrombosis, attenuated organ lesions, and decreased oxidative stress in multiple tissues.
population_specificity: Rats with occluded superior mesenteric vein and artery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of BPC-157 on central nervous system disorders, including stroke, schizophrenia-like symptoms, and spinal cord injury, focusing on its role in the gut-brain axis.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated significant therapeutic effects in counteracting stroke-induced brain damage, resolving schizophrenia-like symptoms, and promoting recovery from spinal cord injury by reducing inflammation and improving nerve function. It also modulated gene expression in hippocampal tissues and addressed dopamine and nitric oxide-system disturbances.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the effects of irremovable occlusion of the superior mesenteric vein and associated multiorgan dysfunction in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 rapidly activated collateral blood flow pathways, restored venous connections, and counteracted hypertension, hypotension, thrombosis, and organ damage, while reducing oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Rats with induced superior mesenteric vein occlusion.
study_duration: Assessments were conducted for 30 minutes post-ligation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could prevent or reverse glaucoma-like symptoms induced by episcleral vein cauterization in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 normalized intraocular pressure, preserved ganglion cells and optic nerve integrity, and counteracted retinal and choroidal vessel irregularities in rats with induced glaucoma. Both prophylactic and curative treatments showed positive effects.
population_specificity: Rats with induced glaucoma-like symptoms via episcleral vein cauterization.
effective_dosage: 0.4 µg/eye, 0.4 ng/eye (local drops); 10 µg/kg, 10 ng/kg (intraperitoneal); 0.16 µg/mL, 0.16 ng/mL (oral, in drinking water).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could prevent and counteract monocrotaline-induced pulmonary arterial hypertension and cor pulmonale in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted monocrotaline-induced pulmonary arterial hypertension, including reversing disturbed parameters, preventing disease progression, and eliminating advanced pulmonary hypertension. Consistent beneficial effects were observed across all treatment regimens.
population_specificity: Rats with monocrotaline-induced pulmonary arterial hypertension.
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg or 10 ng/kg, administered once daily intraperitoneally or continuously in drinking water.
study_duration: Days 1-14, days 1-30 (early regimens), or days 14-30 (delayed regimen).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intra-articular injection of BPC-157, alone or combined with TB4, could relieve knee pain in a primary care setting.
results_summary: The study found that 91.6% of patients receiving BPC-157 alone and 75% of those receiving BPC-157 + TB4 reported significant improvement in knee pain, with an overall 87.5% response rate. No functional or quality-of-life metrics were assessed.
population_specificity: 17 patients (16 surveyed) with various knee pain causes, treated at the Institute for Hormonal Balance in Orlando, Florida.
study_duration: Single injection, follow-up at 6 months to 1 year

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157's effectiveness in wound healing across various tissue types and its potential to counteract bleeding disorders and thrombosis.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated potent wound healing effects by resolving vessel constriction, stabilizing platelet plugs, and improving clot resolution. It also showed efficacy in preventing or attenuating arterial and venous thrombosis and aiding in ischemia/reperfusion scenarios.
population_specificity: Rats with various wound types (cutaneous, colocutaneous, gastrocutaneous, etc.) and induced bleeding disorders.
effective_dosage: Same dose range and equipotent routes across all injuries (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract multiple organ dysfunction syndrome in rats with permanent occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery.
results_summary: BPC-157 rapidly recruited collateral vessels, improved blood flow, attenuated hypertension and hypotension, mitigated ECG disturbances, reduced thrombosis, and largely attenuated multiple organ lesions and disturbances.
population_specificity: Rats with permanent occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg and 10 ng/kg, administered via abdominal bath.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could protect against Clopidogrel-induced gastric injury by reducing inflammation, apoptosis, and promoting angiogenesis.
results_summary: BPC-157 attenuated Clopidogrel-induced gastric mucosal damage by inhibiting ER stress-mediated apoptosis and inflammation while promoting angiogenesis via VEGF-A/VEGFR1-mediated AKT/p38/MAPK pathways. NO blockade weakened BPC-157's protective effects.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats with acetic acid-induced gastric ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could mitigate the effects of superior sagittal sinus occlusion and associated multi-organ damage in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 rapidly reduced brain swelling, normalized vascular pressures, and improved organ function, demonstrating efficacy in both central and peripheral recovery pathways. The peptide was effective even when administered at delayed time points post-occlusion.
population_specificity: Rats with induced superior sagittal sinus occlusion and multi-organ lesions.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg and 10 ng/kg, administered intraperitoneally, intragastrically, or topically at various time points (1 min, 15 min, 24 h, 48 h post-ligation).
study_duration: Variable, with assessments made at multiple time points up to 48 hours post-ligation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract retinal ischemia induced by L-NAME in rats by interacting with the NO-system.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively reversed L-NAME-induced retinal ischemia, restoring normal eye background, choroidal blood vessels, and retinal thickness, while also improving behavioral presentation. The effects were observed whether administered 20 minutes or 48 hours after L-NAME.
population_specificity: Rats with induced retinal ischemia via L-NAME.
effective_dosage: 10 μg (10 ng/kg) retrobulbar application (1 μg/0.1 ml saline per eye).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could attenuate bowel adhesion formation and improve vascular recovery in rats with parietal peritoneum excision, compared to NO-agents.
results_summary: BPC-157 promoted rapid vascular recovery and significantly reduced adhesion formation, even when administered post-treatment. Unlike NO-agents, which had mixed effects, BPC-157 consistently decreased NO- and MDA levels and improved outcomes.
population_specificity: Rats with parietal peritoneum excision and underlying muscle tissue damage.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg, administered once as an abdominal bath or intraperitoneally once daily.
study_duration: Up to 14 days, with post-treatment starting at day 7.
interactions: Maintained beneficial effects when co-administered with NO-agents (L-NAME, L-arginine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of BPC-157 on hippocampal ischemia/reperfusion injuries in rats, focusing on neural damage recovery and functional outcomes.
results_summary: BPC-157 counteracted early and delayed neural hippocampal damage, achieving full functional recovery in memory, locomotion, and coordination. Gene expression studies showed elevated levels of beneficial genes (e.g., Egr1, Akt1) and decreased levels of harmful genes (e.g., Nos2, Nfkb).
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with bilateral clamping of the common carotid arteries.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg applied as a 1 ml bath directly to the operated area.
study_duration: Intervention applied at 30 seconds post-clamping, with outcomes assessed at 24 and 72 hours of reperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the healing effects of BPC-157 on gastrointestinal fistulas and its broader therapeutic potential in wound healing and gastrointestinal integrity.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated consistent healing of various gastrointestinal fistulas (both external and internal) and improved outcomes in impaired gastrointestinal anastomoses, even in the presence of NSAIDs, cysteamine, and other complicating factors. It also showed efficacy in healing diverse wounds, including ulcers, without achieving LD1.
population_specificity: Rats with gastrointestinal fistulas and impaired anastomoses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the damage caused by the Pringle maneuver (portal triad obstruction) in rats, both during ischemia and reperfusion.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively mitigated ECG disturbances, improved hemodynamics, reduced thrombosis, and attenuated organ damage (lung, liver, intestine, spleen, and heart) caused by ischemia-reperfusion injury in rats. It also promoted rapid collateral vessel recruitment to bypass occlusions.
population_specificity: Deeply anesthetized rats subjected to 30-minute portal triad clamping followed by 15-minute or 24-hour reperfusion.
effective_dosage: 10 µg or 10 ng/kg, administered as a single challenge at various time points (before/during ischemia or during reperfusion).
study_duration: Single administration, with effects monitored over 15 minutes or 24 hours post-reperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether BPC-157 could resolve Budd-Chiari syndrome in rats by bypassing inferior vena cava occlusion and improving recovery.
results_summary: BPC-157 rapidly activated bypass pathways, counteracted hypertension and hypotension, reduced thrombosis, and improved organ pathology while maintaining normal liver nitric oxide and malondialdehyde levels.
population_specificity: Rats with suprahepatic occlusion of the inferior vena cava.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng BPC 157, administered once.
study_duration: Single administration at 1 min, 15 min, 24 h, or 48 h post-ligation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the inhibitory effects of antithrombotic agents (aspirin, clopidogrel, cilostazol) on platelet aggregation in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted the inhibitory effects of aspirin, clopidogrel, and cilostazol on platelet aggregation induced by arachidonic acid, ADP, collagen, and arachidonic acid/PGE1, but had no effect on extrinsic/intrinsic hemostasis or fibrin clot parameters.
population_specificity: Rats
interactions: Counteracted effects of aspirin, clopidogrel, and cilostazol on platelet aggregation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of BPC-157 on spinal cord injury recovery in a rat model, focusing on functional and histological improvements.
results_summary: BPC-157 treatment led to consistent clinical improvement, better motor function, reduced spasticity, and counteracted microscopic damage such as vacuole formation, axon loss, and edema. Functional rescue was observed across all stages of secondary injury.
population_specificity: Rat model with induced spinal cord injury (L2-L3 laminectomy and compression).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could attenuate cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis and its interaction with NO-system modulators (L-arginine and L-NAME).
results_summary: BPC-157 significantly reduced cyclophosphamide-induced bladder lesions, inflammation, and functional impairments, both alone and in combination with L-arginine or L-NAME, suggesting a NO-related mechanism.
population_specificity: Rats with cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg/day or 10 ng/kg/day, intraperitoneally or orally in drinking water.
study_duration: Administered after cyclophosphamide induction (3-day cyclophosphamide protocol).
interactions: Interacted with L-arginine (beneficial) and L-NAME (aggravating effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157's role in cytoprotection, organoprotection, and stress coping, as well as its therapeutic potential in wound healing, vascular protection, and mitigating cancer cachexia.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated protective effects on gastric mucosa, endothelium, and multiple organs, improved blood flow integrity, and counteracted muscle wasting and pro-inflammatory cytokines in cancer cachexia. It also showed efficacy in wound healing and vascular recruitment.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical models based on described effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically review the literature on BPC-157 as a feasible therapy for healing and functional restoration of soft tissue damage, focusing on tendon, ligament, and skeletal muscle healing.
results_summary: Studies demonstrated consistently positive and prompt healing effects for various injury types, including traumatic and systemic injuries, across multiple soft tissues. However, most studies were conducted on small rodent models, and human efficacy remains unconfirmed.
population_specificity: Small rodent models (majority), with potential implications for humans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157's role in cytoprotection and adaptive cytoprotection against alcohol-induced lesions in the stomach and other gastrointestinal tissues.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively cured alcohol-induced lesions, enhanced mucosal protection, and restored sphincter pressures, outperforming NO-system agents like L-arginine and L-NAME.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal model implied by dosage units).
study_duration: Immediate post-alcohol administration (timing: 1 min to 24 h).

study_goal: To determine if BPC-157 can attenuate duodenal lesions caused by major venous occlusions, independent of nitric oxide system involvement.
results_summary: BPC-157 significantly reduced mucosal lesions and serosal congestion, improved vessel presentation, and normalized oxidative stress markers (NO and MDA) in duodenal tissues. It also enhanced vascular interconnections and branching by over 60%, bypassing the occlusion effectively.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced superior anterior pancreaticoduodenal vein (SAPDV) ligation.
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg and 10 ng/kg per 1 mL bath/rat, or 10 μg/kg instilled into the stomach.
study_duration: Treatment administered at 1 min post-ligation, with observations up to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract liver fibrosis and portal hypertension in rats with bile duct ligation (BDL).
results_summary: BPC-157 therapy normalized oxidative stress markers (MDA, NO), reduced liver damage markers (AST, ALT, GGT, ALP, bilirubin), and improved liver histology (reduced necrosis, inflammation, fibrosis). It also mitigated portal hypertension and systemic symptoms like jaundice and ascites.
population_specificity: Rats with bile duct ligation (BDL).
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg or 10 ng/kg continuously in drinking water (0.16 μg/ml or 0.16 ng/ml, 12 ml/rat/day); intraperitoneal administration at 30 min post-ligation and 24 h before sacrifice; local bath BPC 157 (10 μg/kg) for portal hypertension.
study_duration: Up to 8 weeks (intervention started immediately post-surgery or at week 4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of BPC-157 in controlling Nosema ceranae infections and improving honeybee colony health.
results_summary: BPC-157 supplementation increased honeybee colony strength and reduced N. ceranae spore loads, while also attenuating midgut damage in infected honeybees.
population_specificity: Honeybee colonies infected with Nosema ceranae.
effective_dosage: 0.1 μg/ml BPC-157 in 0.25 L sugar syrup.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate BPC-157's cytoprotective effects, particularly its ability to protect cells and endothelium outside the stomach, and its role in controlling blood vessel function in response to injury or obstruction.
results_summary: BPC-157 showed significant cytoprotective effects, including healing organ lesions, preventing and reversing thrombosis, and restoring blood flow by activating blood vessels near defects or obstructions. It also counteracted adverse effects of L-NAME and L-arginine.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not detail human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of using Lactococcus lactis as a delivery vector for BPC-157 to reduce reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and treat gastrointestinal inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that BPC-157 delivered via L. lactis significantly decreased ROS production in a fibroblast cell model, with secretion being more effective (117 ng/ml) than surface display (30 ng/ml). The AcmA/Usp45-fusion protein showed superior surface display ability for BPC-157.
population_specificity: 149BR fibroblast cell model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the adverse effects of inferior caval vein ligation in rats, including thrombosis, hemodynamic changes, and tissue damage.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted vein injury, thrombosis, and hemodynamic disturbances, promoted collateral circulation, normalized NO and MDA levels, and modulated gene expression related to vascular function.
population_specificity: Rats with induced inferior caval vein ligation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of BPC-157 on colitis and ischemia-reperfusion injury in rats, focusing on its ability to restore blood supply and counteract oxidative stress.
results_summary: BPC-157 improved vessel presentation, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA and NO), preserved mucosal integrity, and counteracted adverse effects induced by L-NAME and L-arginine. It also promoted tissue recovery in obstructed colon segments.
population_specificity: Rats with induced colitis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, or colon obstruction.
study_duration: Acute effects observed within 15 minutes; long-term effects assessed up to 10 days.
interactions: Counteracted effects of L-NAME and L-arginine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract celecoxib-induced toxicity and assess its interaction with the NO system.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted celecoxib-induced gastrointestinal, liver, and brain lesions, as well as mitigated the negative effects of NO system blockade (L-NAME). It showed consistent benefits across all tested dosages and time points (24h and 48h).
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract cyclophosphamide-induced stomach and duodenal ulcers and oxidative stress in rats, as well as its interaction with the NO-system.
results_summary: BPC-157 attenuated increased NO- and MDA-levels, nullified severe cyclophosphamide-induced ulcers, and counteracted lesions exacerbated by L-NAME, suggesting its protective role against oxidative and ulcerative damage.
population_specificity: Rats treated with cyclophosphamide and L-NAME.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally once a day or in drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate BPC-157's role as an integrative mediator in stress response and its organoprotective effects across various tissues, including gastrointestinal and extragastrointestinal systems.
results_summary: BPC-157 showed significant healing effects in gastrointestinal and extragastrointestinal tissues, counteracted dopamine-system dysfunction, and interacted with serotonin and GABA systems. It also demonstrated cytoprotection, adaptive organoprotection, and beneficial effects on lesions, wounds, and blood disturbances.
population_specificity: Not specified (clinical trials referenced but details not provided).
interactions: Counteracted complications of L-NAME and L-arginine applications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BPC-157 could counteract magnesium toxicity and its effects on cell depolarization in rats, potentially through NO-system-related mechanisms.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted hypermagnesemia and magnesium-induced disturbances, including muscle weakness, lesions, and hyperkalaemia, while also inhibiting cell depolarization in vitro. L-NAME and L-arginine worsened magnesium toxicity, but their combined use with BPC-157 restored control values.
population_specificity: Rats
effective_dosage: 10 µg or 10 ng intraperitoneally, administered once before magnesium injection
interactions: L-NAME and L-arginine worsened magnesium toxicity, but BPC-157 opposed these effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the adverse effects of esophagogastric anastomosis in rats, particularly by addressing NO-system dysfunction and improving healing outcomes.
results_summary: BPC-157 (all regimens) effectively counteracted disease progression, preserved blood vessels, eliminated mortality, and nullified the worsening effects of L-NAME. It also enhanced the benefits of L-arginine, demonstrating a strong therapeutic effect on anastomosis healing and sphincter function.
population_specificity: Rats with esophagogastric anastomosis and esophagocutaneous fistulas.
effective_dosage: 10 μg or 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally once daily, or in drinking water.
interactions: Interacted with L-NAME (NOS-blocker) and L-arginine (NOS substrate), enhancing or counteracting their effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of BPC-157 as a novel mediator in brain-gut axis interactions and its therapeutic effects on CNS disorders, GI tract, and tissue healing.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated strong antiulcer potency, neuroprotective effects, and beneficial impacts on various behavioral disturbances by modulating serotonergic and dopaminergic systems. It also promoted healing in GI tract, liver, pancreas, and various tissues, and attenuated injuries from NSAIDs, insulin overdose, or encephalopathies.
population_specificity: Primarily animal models (rats) and human trials in inflammatory bowel disease and multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157, alone or combined with L-arginine, could counteract the adverse effects of diclofenac and nitric oxide system blockade on wound healing and organ damage in rats following massive small bowel resection.
results_summary: BPC-157 significantly improved anastomosis healing, reduced gastrointestinal, liver, and brain lesions, and counteracted the worsening effects of diclofenac and L-NAME. L-arginine partially ameliorated L-NAME-induced aggravation but was less effective than BPC-157.
population_specificity: Short-bowel rats following massive small bowel resection.
effective_dosage: BPC-157 (10 μg/kg or 10 ng/kg), administered intraperitoneally.
study_duration: Immediate post-surgery intervention, assessed 24 hours later.
interactions: Diclofenac and L-NAME worsened symptoms, while L-arginine partially counteracted L-NAME effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BPC-157 could heal rectovaginal fistulas in rats, based on its known effects on external fistulas.
results_summary: BPC-157, administered orally or intraperitoneally, significantly improved healing of rectovaginal fistulas in rats, reducing defects, leakage, and complications like adhesions and intestinal obstruction. Both microgram and nanogram regimens showed rapid and complete healing.
population_specificity: Rats with surgically induced rectovaginal fistulas.
effective_dosage: 10μg/kg or 10ng/kg, administered perorally in drinking water (0.16μg/ml or 0.16ng/ml, 12ml/rat/day) or intraperitoneally.
study_duration: Treatment continued until sacrifice, with assessments at days 1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 14, and 21.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could heal duodenocutaneous fistulas in rats and assess its interaction with the nitric oxide system.
results_summary: BPC-157 fully counteracted persistent defects, fistula leakage, and sphincter failure in rats, achieving rapid improvement and complete healing. It also nullified the worsening effects of L-NAME and enhanced the benefits of L-arginine.
population_specificity: Rats with duodenocutaneous fistulas.
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg or 10 ng/kg, intraperitoneally or perorally (in drinking water).
interactions: L-NAME (nitric oxide synthase inhibitor) and L-arginine (nitric oxide synthase substrate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157's safety, efficacy in treating gastrointestinal disorders (particularly IBD), and its wound-healing and angiogenic effects.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated a strong safety profile with no reported side effects, efficacy in treating IBD and promoting wound healing, and interaction with the NO-system for endothelium protection and angiogenesis.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and conditions involving impaired wound healing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of BPC-157 on esophagocutaneous fistulas in rats, particularly its interaction with the NO-system and comparison with L-NAME and l-arginine.
results_summary: BPC-157 accelerated fistula healing, reduced leakage, and restored sphincter pressure, counteracting L-NAME effects. It was effective in both μg- and ng-regimens, administered perorally or intraperitoneally, with no mortality reported by day 4.
population_specificity: Rats with established cervical esophagocutaneous fistulas.
effective_dosage: μg- and ng-regimens (specific amounts not detailed).
interactions: Counteracted effects of L-NAME (NOS-blocker) and worked synergistically with l-arginine (NO-substrate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract inflammatory bowel disease (colitis) and multiple sclerosis (cuprizone-induced nerve damage) in rat models.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively promoted healing in colitis and colon-colon anastomosis models and reduced nerve damage in cuprizone-induced multiple sclerosis, particularly in severely affected brain areas. It also improved cerebellar ataxia and forelimb function.
population_specificity: Rat models of colitis and multiple sclerosis (cuprizone-induced nerve damage).
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg or 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally or intragastrically; 0.16 μg/ml or 0.16 ng/ml in drinking water.
study_duration: Varied by model (e.g., until sacrifice at day 4 for cuprizone, up to day 14 for colon-colon anastomosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate BPC-157's effects on hemostasis, particularly its ability to counteract bleeding and thrombocytopenia induced by L-NAME and L-arginine in rats with tail amputation and anticoagulant administration.
results_summary: BPC-157 consistently reduced bleeding time and hemorrhage while counteracting thrombocytopenia in rats, even when combined with L-NAME or L-arginine. It also rescued hemostatic mechanisms disrupted by anticoagulants like heparin and warfarin.
population_specificity: Rats with tail amputation, some treated with heparin or warfarin.
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg, 10 ng/kg (i.p., i.v. for heparin); 10 μg/kg (i.g. for warfarin).
study_duration: 3 days for warfarin administration; other interventions were acute.
interactions: Counteracted effects of L-NAME (thrombocytopenia) and L-arginine (increased hemorrhage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BPC-157 could improve leak point pressure (LPP) recovery in rat models of stress urinary incontinence (SUI) following transabdominal urethrolysis (TU) and prolonged vaginal dilatation (VD).
results_summary: BPC-157 counteracted the decrease in LPP values in TU and VD rats, restoring LPP to levels seen in healthy rats. Immunohistochemical analysis showed improved muscle organization, angiogenesis, and preserved tissue structure in treated rats.
population_specificity: Rats with induced SUI via TU or VD, and healthy rats as controls.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally once daily; 10 µg/kg orally in drinking water (0.16 µg/mL, 12 mL/rat/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BPC-157 could counteract esophagitis, sphincter failure, and acute pancreatitis by addressing their common causative mechanisms.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted esophagitis, sphincter failure, and acute pancreatitis in rats, demonstrating therapeutic potential for these conditions. The study also found that these conditions aggravate each other when combined, but BPC-157 mitigated these effects.
population_specificity: Rats and acute pancreatitis patients (for esophageal manometry).
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg and 10 ng/kg, administered intraperitoneally or in drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BPC-157 could effectively counteract the gastrointestinal, liver, and brain toxicity induced by diclofenac in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 strongly antagonized diclofenac toxicity, preventing severe gastric, intestinal, and liver lesions, reducing elevated bilirubin and liver enzymes, and mitigating brain edema and neuronal damage. The peptide was effective both intraperitoneally and orally at microgram and nanogram doses.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to diclofenac toxicity.
effective_dosage: 10 μg/kg and 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally; 0.16 μg/mL and 0.16 ng/mL orally in drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157's therapeutic potential for gastrointestinal and other organ lesions, including its effects on healing, inflammation, and sphincter function.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated significant healing effects on gastrointestinal lesions, improved sphincter function, and exhibited angiogenic, neuroprotective, and anti-inflammatory properties. It also reversed alcohol- and NSAID-induced damage and promoted fistula closure even with delayed treatment.
population_specificity: Rats with induced gastrointestinal and organ lesions.
study_duration: Varied (e.g., up to one month for fistula closure, 4 weeks for short-bowel syndrome)
interactions: Interacts with the NO-system, dopamine, 5-HT system, and endothelin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BPC-157 could reduce thrombus formation and improve functional recovery after aortic termino-terminal anastomosis in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 (10 µg/kg) reduced thrombus formation, preserved walking ability, and restored muscle strength when administered immediately after anastomosis or intraperitoneally at 24 hours. No thrombus was observed at the anastomosis site in treated rats.
population_specificity: Albino male rats with aortic termino-terminal anastomosis.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg, administered as a bath immediately after anastomosis or intraperitoneally at 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could counteract the adverse effects of insulin overdose, including gastric ulcers, seizures, liver damage, and hypoglycemia in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively prevented fatal outcomes, reduced seizures, minimized liver pathology, preserved glycogen levels, decreased serum enzyme levels, and reduced brain neuron damage in insulin-overdosed rats.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to insulin overdose (250 IU/kg i.p.).
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg, administered intraperitoneally or intragastrically immediately after insulin.
study_duration: Observations made up to 180 minutes post-insulin overdose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate BPC-157's effectiveness in counteracting liver and brain damage caused by extreme paracetamol overdose in rats, focusing on both prophylactic and therapeutic applications.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively prevented convulsions (prophylactic use) or rapidly resolved them (therapeutic use), reduced liver and brain lesions, and lowered enzyme and ammonium serum levels, demonstrating strong antidote potential against paracetamol toxicity.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to extreme paracetamol overdose (5 g/kg intraperitoneally).
effective_dosage: 10 µg, 10 ng, or 10 pg/kg, administered intraperitoneally or intragastrically.
study_duration: Intervention effects observed over a 3-24 hour post-paracetamol period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of BPC-157 on inflammation and bone resorption in experimental periodontitis in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 significantly reduced plasma extravasation, histological signs of inflammation, and alveolar bone resorption in rats with ligature-induced periodontitis, but had no effect on gingivomucosal blood flow in healthy gingiva.
population_specificity: Rats with experimentally induced periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Once daily for 12 days (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 improves healing of medial collateral ligament (MCL) injuries in rats through various administration routes.
results_summary: BPC-157 improved MCL healing in rats when administered intraperitoneally, orally, or topically, demonstrating consistent functional, biomechanical, macroscopic, and histological improvements. The peptide was effective at microgram and nanogram doses without a carrier.
population_specificity: Rats with surgically transected MCL.
effective_dosage: Intraperitoneal (10 µg or 10 ng/kg once daily), topical (1.0 µg dissolved in cream/g), oral (0.16 µg/ml in drinking water, 12 ml/day/rat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could improve muscle healing in rats with muscle crush injuries and counteract corticosteroid-induced impairment.
results_summary: BPC-157 accelerated muscle healing and restored full function, even in the presence of corticosteroid treatment, as demonstrated functionally, macroscopically, and histologically. It completely reversed corticosteroid-impaired muscle healing.
population_specificity: Rats with injured gastrocnemius muscle complex
effective_dosage: Not specified (given intraperitoneally or locally as a cream, once immediately after injury or once daily)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 improves healing and functional recovery in rats with transected sciatic nerves.
results_summary: BPC-157 significantly enhanced nerve regeneration, evidenced by improved histomorphometric, electrophysiological, and functional outcomes, including faster axonal regeneration, increased motor action potentials, and improved walking recovery. Autotomy was absent in treated rats.
population_specificity: Rats with transected sciatic nerves.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could effectively treat short bowel syndrome in rats by promoting intestinal healing and weight recovery.
results_summary: BPC-157 administration (both orally and intraperitoneally) led to immediate weight gain, improved intestinal structure (villus height, crypt depth, muscle thickness), normalized jejunal and ileal diameters, and increased anastomosis strength in rats with short bowel syndrome.
population_specificity: Rats with induced short bowel syndrome via small bowel resection.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg, administered daily in drinking water (12 ml/rat/day) or intraperitoneally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 accelerates healing in crushed muscle injuries and transected tendons, and its potential clinical relevance for muscle crush injuries.
results_summary: BPC-157 improved muscle healing macroscopically (reduced hematoma and edema, no leg contracture), microscopically, functionally, and via enzyme activity markers, with effectiveness both locally and intraperitoneally.
population_specificity: Crushed rats (gastrocnemius muscle complex injury).
effective_dosage: Applied intraperitoneally or locally as a thin cream layer immediately after injury and once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could prevent and counteract digitalis-induced arrhythmias in rats, particularly through its interaction with the NO-system.
results_summary: BPC-157 reduced ventricular premature beats, prolonged the onset of ventricular tachycardia, and mitigated AV-block duration in digitalis-challenged rats. It also showed prophylactic and therapeutic efficacy, with higher doses preventing fatal outcomes and lower doses delaying them.
population_specificity: Rats with digitalis-induced arrhythmias.
effective_dosage: 50 µg, 10 µg, and 10 ng/kg (intravenous and intraperitoneal).
study_duration: Immediate to short-term (e.g., 20 seconds post-AV-block for therapeutic intervention).
interactions: Interaction with the NO-system (L-NAME and L-arginine effects noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of BPC-157 on persistent colocutaneous fistula healing in rats and its relationship with nitric oxide (NO) modulation.
results_summary: BPC-157 accelerated healing of colonic and skin defects, improved fistula closure, and maintained functionality, even with blunted NO generation. L-NAME worsened healing, while L-arginine was only effective with blunted NO. BPC-157's benefits remained consistent regardless of NO modulation.
population_specificity: Rats with surgically induced colocutaneous fistulas.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg, administered either in drinking water or once daily intraperitoneally.
interactions: Interactions noted with L-NAME, L-arginine, sulphasalazine, and 6-alpha-methylprednisolone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 is more effective than standard agents in healing gastrocutaneous fistulas and persistent gastric ulcers, particularly under corticosteroid aggravation.
results_summary: BPC-157 demonstrated superior healing effects on both skin and stomach mucosa, even after corticosteroid aggravation, compared to standard anti-ulcer agents. It improved fistula closure and prevented leakage, while standard agents showed delayed and limited efficacy.
population_specificity: Rats with surgically induced gastrocutaneous fistulas.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg in drinking water (12 ml/rat/day) or intraperitoneally (10 µg/kg, 10 ng/kg, 10 pg/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of BPC-157 and methylprednisolone on early functional recovery and inflammation in a rat model of Achilles tendon-to-bone transection.
results_summary: BPC-157 improved functional recovery by reducing inflammation (lower myeloperoxidase activity and inflammatory cell influx) and promoting new blood vessel formation, while methylprednisolone reduced inflammation but hindered blood vessel formation and did not improve functional recovery.
population_specificity: Male Wistar Albino rats with surgically transected Achilles tendons.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg BPC-157, administered intraperitoneally once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could alleviate esophagitis and improve sphincter pressure in rats with induced sphincter failure.
results_summary: BPC-157 treatment alleviated esophagitis and normalized pressure in both the pyloric and lower esophageal sphincters, while ranitidine had no effect. In normal rats, BPC-157 increased lower esophageal sphincter pressure but decreased pyloric sphincter pressure.
population_specificity: Rats with induced sphincter failure and esophagitis, as well as normal rats.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg or 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally once daily; 0.16 µg/ml or 0.16 ng/ml continuously in drinking water (12 ml/rat per day); or direct stomach administration before pressure assessment.
study_duration: Treatment lasted until 24 hours before assessment, with follow-up at 7 days, 14 days, or 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could improve healing and functional restoration in completely transected quadriceps muscle and Achilles tendon in rats.
results_summary: BPC-157 consistently improved muscle healing, including biomechanical strength, functional recovery, microscopic regeneration, and macroscopic presentation, with no reported toxicity. The peptide restored near-normal muscle structure and function over a 72-day period.
population_specificity: Rats with completely transected quadriceps muscle and Achilles tendon.
effective_dosage: 10 µg, 10 ng, or 10 pg/kg intraperitoneally, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate BPC-157's effects on serotonin syndrome in rats, specifically its ability to counteract symptoms induced by MAO-inhibition and serotonin precursor administration.
results_summary: BPC-157 significantly reduced serotonin syndrome symptoms, including hyperthermia and wet dog shakes, particularly counteracting 5-HT2A receptor-related disturbances. It showed efficacy at various doses, with higher doses counteracting milder symptoms.
population_specificity: Rats with induced serotonin syndrome via pargyline (MAO-inhibitor) and L-tryptophan (serotonin precursor).
interactions: Counteracted effects of pargyline and L-tryptophan; no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 could effectively treat prolonged esophagitis and recover failed sphincters in a rat model.
results_summary: BPC-157 treatment recovered esophagitis (macroscopically and microscopically) and restored pressure in both lower esophageal and pyloric sphincters, while ranitidine had no effect. The peptide's effects were specific, increasing lower esophageal sphincter pressure in normal rats but decreasing pyloric sphincter pressure.
population_specificity: Rats with prolonged esophagitis and sphincter failure.
effective_dosage: 10 µg/kg intraperitoneally once daily or 0.16 µg/ml continuously in drinking water (12 ml/rat).
study_duration: Treatment lasted until 24 hours before assessment; initial challenges were evaluated at 12 or 20 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 improves healing of CO(2) laser injuries in mice and assess its effectiveness when applied topically.
results_summary: BPC-157 consistently improved healing of CO(2) laser injuries in mice, both macroscopically and microscopically, with the most effective dosage being 1 microg/g in neutral cream. The peptide demonstrated favorable stability and effectiveness without requiring a carrier.
population_specificity: Male NMRI-Hannover mice with CO(2) laser-induced dorsal skin injuries.
effective_dosage: 1 microg, 1 ng, or 1 pg BPC-157 per gram of neutral cream, applied topically once daily.
study_duration: Treatment lasted up to 21 days, with the first application 60 minutes post-injury and the last 24 hours before euthanasia.

study_goal: To investigate the protective effects of BPC-157 on acute and chronic gastric ulcers in rats and compare its efficacy via different administration methods (intramuscular vs. intragastric).
results_summary: Both intramuscular and intragastric administration of BPC-157 reduced ulcer area and accelerated healing, with intramuscular administration showing superior efficacy. Higher dosages (400 ng/kg, 800 ng/kg) significantly reduced lesions, and continuous application improved glandular epithelium regeneration and granulation tissue formation.
population_specificity: Rats with induced acute and chronic gastric ulcers.
effective_dosage: 200 ng/kg, 400 ng/kg, and 800 ng/kg (single or continuous administration).
study_duration: Not specified (acute and chronic models used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BPC-157 improves healing in transected Achilles tendons in rats and its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: BPC-157 significantly improved tendon healing biomechanically, functionally, microscopically, and macroscopically, with enhanced recovery of tendon integrity and opposition to negative growth modulators like HNE.
population_specificity: Rats with transected Achilles tendons.
effective_dosage: 10 µg, 10 ng, or 10 pg/kg body weight, administered intraperitoneally once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate BPC-157's ability to counteract hyperkalemia-induced effects, including arrhythmias, muscular weakness, and sphincter dysfunction, and its interaction with the NO-system.
results_summary: BPC-157 effectively counteracted hyperkalemia-induced disturbances, restored normal sinus rhythm, and nullified lesions, with no additive effect when combined with l-arginine. It also directly affected potassium conductance in vitro.
population_specificity: Animal models (in vivo) and HEK293 cells (in vitro).
study_duration: Single-dose administration (30min before or 10min after KCl).
interactions: Combined with l-arginine, but no additive effect noted. L-NAME aggravated outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of BPC-157 as a therapeutic peptide for enhancing recovery, tissue repair, and performance optimization in high-level athletes and bodybuilders.
results_summary: Early in vivo research suggests BPC-157 may optimize endurance training, metabolism, recovery, and tissue repair, but clinical evidence in orthopedic applications remains scarce. The abstract highlights the growing interest in therapeutic peptides despite limited literature on clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: High-level athletes and bodybuilders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if BPC-157 could counteract corticosteroid-impaired healing in thermally injured mice and assess its effects on burn healing and burn-gastric lesions.
results_summary: BPC-157 improved burn healing, counteracted corticosteroid-impaired healing, exhibited anti-ulcer effects, and reversed corticosteroid-induced immunosuppression in mice.
population_specificity: Male NMRI-Hannover mice with thermal injuries.
effective_dosage: BPC-157 cream at three different levels (1 microg/g cream mentioned for in vitro assessment).
study_duration: Treatment lasted up to 21 days, with daily applications.

study_goal: To evaluate the feasibility of intracranial lead reconstruction in DBS therapy for Parkinsonism and assess its association with clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Patients showed postoperative improvements in Hoehn-Yahr stage, UPDRS Ⅲ score, SE-ADL score, and LEDD, but only those with bilateral stimulating contacts in the STN maintained improvements at 12 months. Lead reconstruction and standard programming selected matching optimal contacts 77.78% of the time.
population_specificity: 27 patients with Parkinson's disease who received bilateral STN DBS therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of BPC-157, administered topically or systemically, on burn healing and gastric lesions in burned mice.
results_summary: BPC-157 improved burn healing parameters, reduced inflammation and necrosis, enhanced collagen formation, and attenuated gastric lesions in burned mice, outperforming controls and silver sulfadiazine.
population_specificity: Mice with deep partial skin thickness burns covering 20% of total body area.
effective_dosage: 10 µg or 10 ng/kg intraperitoneally; topically as 50 µg, 5 µg, 500 ng, 50 ng, or 5 ng mixed in cream.
study_duration: Daily until 24 hours before sacrifice (up to 21 days).
